metadata.case_name: Sunder Lal Son v. Bharat Handicrafts Private Ltd.

facts.text: Appellants Messrs Sunder Lal Son are members of the East India Jute and Hessian Exchange Ltd., an Association recognised under the Forward Contracts Regulation Act, 1952.

Appellants entered into contract No. 750 dated September 16, 1960 with respondents for purchase of 6,00,000 bags of B Twill at Rs. 132.50 per 100 bags, on their own account in Transferable Specific Delivery Form prescribed under the bye-laws of the Association.

Bought and sold notes issued: Sold note from Bharat Handicrafts Private Ltd. to Sunder Lal Son; Bought note from Sunder Lal Son to Bharat Handicrafts Private Ltd., subject to terms and conditions, signed by appellants as Member Licensed Broker.
Respondents denied existence and validity of the contract.
Appellants applied to Calcutta High Court original side under s.33 Indian Arbitration Act 1940 for order declaring valid arbitration agreement contained in contract No. 750.

Calcutta High Court dismissed application on May 13, 1963 in Award Case No. 119 of 1963, holding contract invalid as it did not comply with s.15 sub-s.4 Forward Contracts Regulation Act, 1952; also held appellants not proved members.
Respondents in their City Civil Court plaint para 6 admitted appellants were members of the Association at all material times.
Confirmation slip detached from sold note not produced in High Court; appellants sought to tender it in Supreme Court, purporting to bear confirmation by M.L. Bahati, but not allowed.
Central Government issued notification declaring s.15(1) applicable to forward contracts in jute and jute goods.
Respondents are not members of the Association.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellants were members of the Association at the time of formation of the contract.
Whether the contract complies with requirements of s.15(4) Forward Contracts Regulation Act, 1952, particularly disclosure and consent/authority in writing.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellants were at all material times members of the Association.

Contract valid; bought and sold notes in prescribed form; respondents gave confirmation slip; s.15(4) does not invalidate contract for lack of written confirmation, only exposes to penalty under s.20(2).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Forward Contracts Regulation Act, 1952 s.15(4), s.20(2); Shri Bajrang Jute Mills Ltd. v. Lalchand Dugar

petitioner_arguments.text: Form of notes prescribed by bye-laws; must be used even for own account transactions.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bye-laws of Association under s.11 Forward Contracts Regulation Act

respondent_arguments.text: Appellants were not members of the Association at relevant time.
Contract invalid for non-compliance with s.15(4) Forward Contracts Regulation Act: no disclosure in notes that on own account, no consent/authority secured.

court_reasoning.text: Appellants proved members due to respondents' admission in City Civil Court plaint para 6; respondents do not support High Court on this ground.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Admission in plaint constitutes evidence of membership.

court_reasoning.text: No evidence of written consent/authority or confirmation within 3 days; confirmation slip not produced in High Court, not allowed in Supreme Court under CPC O.41 r.27 as no substantial cause.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Document in possession but not tendered; does not prove itself without further evidence.

court_reasoning.text: s.15(4) requires disclosure in note/memorandum and consent/authority (written or confirmed in writing within 3 days) for enforceable contract on own account with non-member; absence makes contract invalid, not merely penal under s.20(2).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prohibition in public interest; writing condition precedent for enforceability; rejects view in Shri Bajrang Jute Mills that proviso directory.

court_reasoning.text: s.15(1) makes non-member contracts illegal; s.15(2) voids for bye-law contravention; s.15(4) prohibits own account without disclosure and consent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act imposes restrictions for public protection against malpractices.

holdings.text: Appellants were members of the Association.
Contract does not comply with s.15(4) Forward Contracts Regulation Act, 1952 due to lack of disclosure and written consent/confirmation; hence invalid and unenforceable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shri Bajrang Jute Mills Ltd. v. Lalchand Dugar
precedents_cited.relevance: Rejected view that s.15(4) proviso directory and failure to obtain written confirmation does not invalidate contract.

statutes_cited.name: Forward Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates forward contracts; s.15(4) prohibits and invalidates own account contracts with non-members without disclosure and consent; penalty under s.20(2).

statutes_cited.name: Indian Arbitration Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for High Court application to declare arbitration agreement valid.

outcome.summary: Appeal against High Court dismissal of application under s.33 Arbitration Act dismissed; contract held invalid for non-compliance with s.15(4) FCRA.

key_quotes.text: "So long as there is no writing as is contemplated by s.15(4) or the proviso thereto, there is no enforceable contract."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on enforceability under s.15(4).

key_quotes.text: "The prohibition imposed by cl.4 is not imposed in the interest of revenue the clause is apparently conceived in the larger interest of the public to protect them against the malpractices indulged in by members."
key_quotes.speaker: court
